label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, April 26, 1945
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, advising her on how to attempt to sell Medway Plantation and join him in Hawaii.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
31		4 26 45
I loved your description of the paved streets, fat over
fed people and the non existing knowledge that a war is going
on. Those were the things that made em like New York. I did
not want to be reminded that the war was going on when I was
there. I was delighted to see the fat people because that
meant there must be good food to eat and I could get fat too.
The trains did not bother me. I never had any difficulty at
all in getting drawing rooms and compartments even at the
last minute, in fact both Morris and I thought it a lot of
huey about the transportation difficulties we had been told
to expect. You however have so much explorer blood in you that
you are miserable unless you are starving or suffering terribly,
or so active that it amounts to practically the same thing.
I think I will have to find some kind of an electrical horse
or some machine that will give you a quick work out in the
morning before I get out of bed in order that you will only
have the energies of a normal person by the time I shuffle up
to the breakfast table for a little nourishment.
When I said sell Medway you will note that I always specific
selling what was our original purchase, the Medway house and
the 2200 acres that went with it. I want to keep Pine and
Spring Grove. On them you have the best quail and duck shooting,
will grow for the horses and low maintenance. I would keep
the little spring grove house as a shooting box. Make it a
little more attractive. Paint the fence around the paddock
and the barn,keep a dozen chickens, three horses, two bird
dogs, Walter and David as the two men and Rosa as the women.
We would go there for the shooting and riding without a worry
in the world. The timber would grow and support the small
in the world. The timber would grow and support the small
upkeep of the place with proper t mebering under a forrestor,
with our supervision. Then we would go to New York for a week
or two , stay in the Hampshire House, drink Champagne, whirl
around, jumping up and down and then leave and return to this
pearl of the Pacific. If our income dropped so low as to
make this picture impossible you could take in washing or
perhaps building an empire in the mornings while I am waking up.
You know the taxes on these two peices of property are
nothing. The insurance mounts to thirty dollars a year or so.
xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx The insurance on Medway alone is $3500. Taces
are on the same ratio.However do nothing until you come out
here and see this place, live here a while and see if the
climate agrees with you, then you will be able to make your
decision easier. It helps one to see things so much clearer
and in a proper prospecit e whn you are away, or at least I
think it does.
Let me know what is happening. I really think it will
be alright this time. With all my love and a big hsg and kiss
[End Page 1]
Please excuse my not writing before, but everytime I
was about to start I thought that the next mail would bring a 
letter from you saying that you had made the necessary arrangement
s. However the last one that I received said that it was necessar
y for Stanton to request your services. I judged by this
that you had not received my letteradvising that margaret
had spoken to Stanton and that he was going to see you in
Washington and get in touch with you. When I first spoke
to her she said there was not a chance but on calling her
again the next morning she said that Stanton had promised if
arrangements could be made he would do it. Really it looks
as if everything may go through. Of course you may be taken
prisoner again by a pack of doodles or some other ferious
array but it seems to me that luck will break and everything
come out alright.
Finally after six weeks the sun was in the sky again
today and I rushed forth at my lunchoen hour to absorb a little
and see if I could not exchange the green pallor that lay over
my face like a shroud for a little red. Unfortunately I did
not succeed completely andto night my face is streaked with
lines of green and red so that I look something like that famous
green or blue stripped tiger that we went to Indo China for.
After dinner I left Morris who had fever of one hundred and two
as a result of his typhoid shot and went up to the cliff
overlooking the beach. The sea stretched to the horizon a xxx
rippled sheet of gold while on the beach the waveslooked like
frozen yellow cream. I sat there for an hour watching the sea,
like xxxxxxxxxxxx black rocks glistening and the almost ghost
line of white breakers cut of thepath of the moon.
I had taken a captains car back to his wife. The captain
had left the office with the request that we deliver this car and
when I drove up to the house I heard a wailing like that of a
frightened child. You know how I feel about children especially
crying ones, but as I beat a hasty retreat the wife said that
is poor Sampson. I thought that Sampson was making hell of
a lot of noise biblical character or not, but Sampson turned
our to be a cat that had climbed a cocanut palm and could not
get down. Let me take this opportunity to tell you that I
did not climb that tree and rescue Sampson. Those days are 
long past. Neither id I stand under the tree and speak soft
talk , "Kitty Kitty, sweet pussy come down" I said let the dam
cat stay up there, maybe he will fall out and break his neck.
This story I tell you in order that you may expect to see my
my sullen jowls, scowling brow and bald head when God brings
us together again. Also please either send or bring me
enough material to puxt in patched in the back of all my trousers
in order that I can make the waist line larger.
[End Page 2]
